trans-unit.source: Sends a string of characters to a control.

seg-source.mrk: Sends a string of characters to a control.

target.mrk: Sends a string of characters to a control.

trans-unit.source: The title/hWnd/class of the window to access. See Title special definition.

seg-source.mrk: The title/hWnd/class of the window to access.

target.mrk: The title/hWnd/class of the window to access.

trans-unit.source: The text of the window to access. See Text special definition.

seg-source.mrk: The text of the window to access.

target.mrk: The text of the window to access.

trans-unit.source: The control to interact with. See Controls.
String of characters to send to the control.

seg-source.mrk: String of characters to send to the control.

target.mrk: String of characters to send to the control.

trans-unit.source: $SEND_DEFAULT (0) = Text contains special characters like + and ! to indicate SHIFT and ALT key-presses (default).

seg-source.mrk: $SEND_DEFAULT (0) = Text contains special characters like + and !
to indicate SHIFT and ALT key-presses (default).

target.mrk: $SEND_DEFAULT (0) = Text contains special characters like + and !
to indicate SHIFT and ALT key-presses (default).

trans-unit.source: ControlSend() works in a similar way to Send() but it can send key strokes directly to a window/control, rather than just to the active window.

seg-source.mrk: ControlSend() works in a similar way to Send() but it can send key strokes directly to a window/control, rather than just to the active window.

target.mrk: ControlSend() works in a similar way to Send() but it can send key strokes directly to a window/control, rather than just to the active window.

trans-unit.source: ControlSend() is only unreliable for command prompts as that works differently to normal windows (seems to check physical states rather than accepting the keystroke messages). For normal windows ControlSend() should be way more reliable than a normal Send() - and yes it does send shift, ctrl, alt etc.

seg-source.mrk: ControlSend() is only unreliable for command prompts as that works differently to normal windows (seems to check physical states rather than accepting the keystroke messages).
For normal windows ControlSend() should be way more reliable than a normal Send() - and yes it does send shift, ctrl, alt etc.

target.mrk: ControlSend() is only unreliable for command prompts as that works differently to normal windows (seems to check physical states rather than accepting the keystroke messages).
For normal windows ControlSend() should be way more reliable than a normal Send() - and yes it does send shift, ctrl, alt etc.

trans-unit.source: As mention in the Send() help the keyboard that send different chars when in CAPS LOCK and using the Shift Key cannot be simulated. An example is the Czech Keyboard. A good workaround is to use the ControlSetText().

seg-source.mrk: As mention in the Send() help the keyboard that send different chars when in CAPS LOCK and using the Shift Key cannot be simulated.
An example is the Czech Keyboard.
A good workaround is to use the ControlSetText().

target.mrk: As mention in the Send() help the keyboard that send different chars when in CAPS LOCK and using the Shift Key cannot be simulated.
An example is the Czech Keyboard.
A good workaround is to use the ControlSetText().

trans-unit.source: The control might first need to be given focus with the ControlFocus() command, specially when referencing an controlID created by the script itself.

seg-source.mrk: The control might first need to be given focus with the ControlFocus() command, specially when referencing an controlID created by the script itself.

target.mrk: The control might first need to be given focus with the ControlFocus() command, specially when referencing an controlID created by the script itself.

trans-unit.source: Opt("SendKeyDelay",...) alters the length of the brief pause in between sent keystrokes.

seg-source.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDelay",...) alters the length of the brief pause in between sent keystrokes.

target.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDelay",...) alters the length of the brief pause in between sent keystrokes.

trans-unit.source: Opt("SendKeyDownDelay",...) alters the length of time a key is held down before being released during a keystroke.

seg-source.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDownDelay",...) alters the length of time a key is held down before being released during a keystroke.

target.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDownDelay",...) alters the length of time a key is held down before being released during a keystroke.

trans-unit.source: Wait 10 seconds for the Notepad window to appear.

seg-source.mrk: Wait 10 seconds for the Notepad window to appear.

target.mrk: Wait 10 seconds for the Notepad window to appear.

trans-unit.source: Send a string of text to the edit control of Notepad. The handle returned by WinWait is used for the "title" parameter of ControlSend.

seg-source.mrk: Send a string of text to the edit control of Notepad.
The handle returned by WinWait is used for the "title" parameter of ControlSend.

target.mrk: Send a string of text to the edit control of Notepad.
The handle returned by WinWait is used for the "title" parameter of ControlSend.

trans-unit.source: Close the Notepad window using the handle returned by WinWait.

seg-source.mrk: Close the Notepad window using the handle returned by WinWait.

target.mrk: Close the Notepad window using the handle returned by WinWait.

trans-unit.source: Now a screen will pop up and ask to save the changes, the classname of the window is called

seg-source.mrk: Now a screen will pop up and ask to save the changes, the classname of the window is called

target.mrk: Now a screen will pop up and ask to save the changes, the classname of the window is called

trans-unit.source: "#32770" and simulating the "TAB" key to move to the second button in which the "ENTER" is simulated to not "save the file"
